thread.title: More than a game, Braylen's touchdown
thread.title_full: More than a game, Braylen's touchdown

title: More than a game, Braylen's touchdown
text:
/ Headlines List / Article 
WHITESBURG, Ky (WYMT) - For most little league football teams an undefeated season is what dreams are made of, but for the West Whitesburg Yellow Jackets when they look back on this successful season, the number in the win column wont be the first memory that comes to mind. 
"We didn't think that he was going to play." Said Carrie Hall, Braylen and Clayton's mother. 
Clayton Hall is a member of the Yellow Jackets, and while he loves playing the game of football, this nine year old is wise beyond his years. 
"I think it's very important, I'm glad that it's on there and it reminds me of Bray in the games." Said Clayton Hall. 
Clay has a twin named Braylen. Braylen has autism. He has a very important job during games. 
"To be a water boy." Said Braylen Hall. 
"(He's a) water boy, motivational speaker, he's been a little of everything. A doctor, he'll do it all for you." Said Head Coach William Bolling. 
Bray does all he can on the sideline to lift up his teammates during games, but during one particular game, his teammates were the ones lifting him up. 
"At three minutes and 56 seconds left in the game, Braylen's dad and I had no idea that was going to happen." Said Carrie. 
It was the last of the regular season for West Whitesburg and head coach William Bolling told Bray to dress in full uniform that night. 
"My heart just sunk to my stomach." Said Carrie. 
"I just got a touchdown and it was awesome." Said Braylen. 
"It was amazing. There weren't many dry eyes in the crowd." Said Carrie. 
The tears flowed freely in the stands. Even on the sideline Bray's teammates felt the weight of the moment. 
"It was really good. Me, myself, I almost cried. I was so happy for him." Said Bray's teammate and friend Jackson Bolling. 
"When Bray got on the sideline, everybody was like, 'Good job, Bray!' Someone picked him and everyone went over there and gave him hugs." Said Braylen's brother Clayton. 
On this little league team, the idea of playing for more than yourself is a concept they already understand. 
"It makes me remember Bray and all the kids that have autism." 
"I think it's going to be life-changing for him. It's definitely going to be a moment that he'll never forget, ever." Said Bray's mom Carrie. 
An unforgettable moment that holds more value than any win on a football field by a boy whose dreams far exceed that 59 yard touchdown run.
